Abstract
SocialÂ benefitsÂ canÂ potentiallyÂ playÂ anÂ importantÂ roleÂ inÂ protectingÂ theÂ poorÂ andÂ minimizingÂ theÂ impactsÂ ofÂ anÂ economicÂ crisis.Â WhileÂ manyÂ studiesÂ estimateÂ theÂ impactsÂ ofÂ aÂ crisis,Â thereÂ isÂ littleÂ evidenceÂ ofÂ theÂ actualÂ responseÂ ofÂ socialÂ safetyÂ netsÂ toÂ systematicÂ shocks.Â ThisÂ studyÂ tracesÂ theÂ responseÂ ofÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ duringÂ theÂ 2008â€?10Â globalÂ crisisÂ forÂ 14Â countriesÂ inÂ ECA.Â TheÂ studyÂ firstÂ setsÂ outÂ aÂ frameworkÂ forÂ definingÂ theÂ â€œexpectedâ€?Â responseÂ ofÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ coveringÂ anÂ assessmentÂ ofÂ preâ€?crisisÂ preparednessÂ ofÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ andÂ theÂ severityÂ ofÂ theÂ crisisÂ forÂ allÂ countriesÂ inÂ theÂ ECAÂ regionÂ toÂ provideÂ theÂ context;Â andÂ thenÂ developsÂ aÂ typologyÂ ofÂ allÂ countriesÂ categorizedÂ byÂ expectedÂ response.Â UsingÂ thisÂ typologyÂ theÂ studyÂ analyzesÂ theÂ monthlyÂ administrativeÂ dataÂ onÂ theÂ observedÂ patternsÂ withinÂ socialÂ benefitÂ programs.Â MainÂ findingsÂ indicateÂ thatÂ actualÂ responsesÂ wereÂ largelyÂ inÂ lineÂ withÂ expectations.Â Preâ€?crisisÂ preparednessÂ clearlyÂ influencedÂ theÂ abilityÂ ofÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ toÂ respondÂ toÂ theÂ crisis.Â UnemploymentÂ benefitsÂ wereÂ generallyÂ theÂ firstÂ lineÂ ofÂ responseÂ inÂ countriesÂ thatÂ haveÂ them,Â whileÂ socialÂ assistanceÂ programsÂ alsoÂ expandedÂ coverageÂ duringÂ theÂ crisis.Â LessonsÂ learnedÂ fromÂ theÂ 2008â€?2010Â globalÂ crisisÂ (suchÂ asÂ theÂ importanceÂ ofÂ structuralÂ reform,Â design,Â andÂ implementationÂ whichÂ affectÂ theÂ successÂ ofÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ programsÂ inÂ crisisÂ response)Â areÂ alsoÂ presented.Â Â TheÂ studyÂ concludesÂ withÂ someÂ policyÂ recommendationsÂ toÂ helpÂ ECAÂ countriesÂ prepareÂ forÂ futureÂ crises.Â Â

incomeÂ countries.Â EligibilityÂ thresholdsÂ forÂ povertyâ€?targetedÂ programsÂ areÂ commonlyÂ veryÂ rigidÂ andÂ tooÂ narrow,Â whichÂ resultÂ inÂ largeÂ errorsÂ ofÂ exclusionÂ andÂ limitÂ crisisÂ responses.Â BenefitsÂ areÂ alsoÂ fragmented,Â asÂ mostÂ countriesÂ operateÂ numerousÂ programsÂ withÂ diverseÂ applicationÂ proceduresÂ andÂ eligibilityÂ rules.Â NavigatingÂ multipleÂ schemesÂ isÂ costlyÂ forÂ theÂ beneficiariesÂ andÂ parallelÂ administrationÂ isÂ costlyÂ forÂ governments;Â gapsÂ andÂ duplicationsÂ abound.Â BenefitsÂ administrationÂ inÂ manyÂ instancesÂ isÂ alsoÂ weak,Â withÂ paperâ€?basedÂ recordsÂ andÂ inadequateÂ managementÂ informationÂ systemsÂ orÂ oversightÂ andÂ controls.Â Â

InÂ orderÂ toÂ assessÂ theÂ preâ€?crisisÂ (asÂ ofÂ 2008)Â preparednessÂ ofÂ theÂ SocialÂ BenefitsÂ systemsÂ inÂ EuropeÂ andÂ CentralÂ AsiaÂ countries,Â weÂ developedÂ aÂ compositeÂ scoreÂ basedÂ onÂ severalÂ dimensions.Â Â TheseÂ dimensionsÂ relateÂ toÂ threeÂ broadÂ areas:Â Â theÂ compositionÂ ofÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ (i.e.Â theÂ existenceÂ ofÂ theÂ typesÂ ofÂ programsÂ thatÂ couldÂ beÂ leveragedÂ inÂ crisisÂ response),Â theÂ performanceÂ ofÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ (withÂ respectÂ toÂ overallÂ performanceÂ indicatorsÂ suchÂ asÂ targetingÂ accuracy,Â coverageÂ etc.),Â andÂ theÂ informationÂ capacityÂ asÂ anÂ indicatorÂ ofÂ theÂ efficacyÂ ofÂ theÂ administrationÂ ofÂ benefitÂ programs.40Â Â Â Â
WhileÂ theseÂ indicatorsÂ coverÂ aÂ goodÂ portionÂ ofÂ theÂ relevantÂ information,Â theÂ resultingÂ indexÂ isÂ notÂ aÂ preciseÂ measure.Â ThereÂ areÂ manyÂ otherÂ factorsÂ (suchÂ asÂ qualityÂ ofÂ implementation,Â administrativeÂ capacityÂ toÂ handleÂ increaseÂ inÂ applications,Â designÂ issuesÂ suchÂ asÂ easeÂ ofÂ applicationÂ etc.)Â thatÂ areÂ difficultÂ toÂ measureÂ andÂ thereforeÂ cannotÂ beÂ included.Â Moreover,Â compositeÂ indicesÂ canÂ beÂ constructedÂ inÂ manyÂ differentÂ waysÂ (simpleÂ average,Â weightedÂ averageÂ etc.).Â However,Â theÂ conceptÂ wasÂ toÂ sortÂ countriesÂ basedÂ onÂ theÂ availableÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ information,Â andÂ theÂ indexÂ usedÂ inÂ thisÂ studyÂ reflectsÂ ourÂ bestÂ judgment.Â
Specifically,Â aÂ compositeÂ scoreÂ forÂ eachÂ countryÂ wasÂ calculatedÂ usingÂ householdÂ surveyÂ data,Â asÂ wellÂ asÂ administrativeÂ information.Â Â Â TheÂ compositeÂ scoreÂ wasÂ comprisedÂ ofÂ nineÂ dimensionsÂ covering:Â (a)Â existenceÂ andÂ performanceÂ ofÂ lastÂ resortÂ socialÂ assistanceÂ (LRSA)Â programsÂ (coverage,Â targetingÂ accuracy,Â generosityÂ â€“Â allÂ fromÂ householdÂ surveyÂ data,Â latestÂ preâ€?crisisÂ year);Â (b)Â existenceÂ andÂ coverageÂ ofÂ unemploymentÂ benefitsÂ (again,Â preâ€?crisis);Â (c)Â existenceÂ andÂ performanceÂ ofÂ childÂ /Â familyÂ allowanceÂ programsÂ (coverage,Â targetingÂ accuracy,Â generosity);Â andÂ (c)Â informationÂ capacityÂ (degreeÂ toÂ whichÂ administrativeÂ dataÂ onÂ socialÂ benefitsÂ areÂ available,Â sinceÂ theseÂ areÂ neededÂ forÂ monitoringÂ andÂ expansionÂ ofÂ socialÂ benefits).Â Â Â DetailsÂ onÂ eachÂ aspectÂ ofÂ theÂ compositeÂ scoreÂ follow.Â

TheÂ informationÂ capacityÂ isÂ alsoÂ consideredÂ asÂ anÂ indicatorÂ ofÂ theÂ efficacyÂ ofÂ theÂ administrationÂ ofÂ benefitÂ programsÂ â€“Â especiallyÂ sinceÂ informationÂ monitoringÂ systemsÂ wouldÂ beÂ neededÂ toÂ monitorÂ theÂ crisisÂ andÂ processÂ anÂ increaseÂ inÂ applicationsÂ duringÂ aÂ crisis.Â ThisÂ indicatorÂ isÂ admittedlyÂ aÂ somewhatÂ subjectiveÂ evaluation.Â ItÂ takesÂ intoÂ accountÂ theÂ degreeÂ toÂ whichÂ informationÂ isÂ readilyÂ availableÂ onÂ numbersÂ ofÂ applicants,Â beneficiaries,Â andÂ spendingÂ onÂ SBÂ programs,Â whichÂ canÂ beÂ anÂ indicatorÂ ofÂ efficacyÂ ofÂ programÂ managementÂ (benefitsÂ administration).Â ThisÂ canÂ alsoÂ signalÂ theÂ needÂ forÂ structuralÂ improvementsÂ inÂ theÂ mediumÂ term.Â InÂ addition,Â ifÂ theÂ authoritiesÂ doÂ notÂ haveÂ theÂ informationÂ itÂ wouldÂ beÂ harderÂ toÂ monitorÂ andÂ respond/interveneÂ asÂ needed.Â AfterÂ all,Â theÂ abilityÂ toÂ respondÂ isÂ veryÂ dependentÂ onÂ havingÂ information.Â Â

WeÂ developÂ theÂ compositeÂ scoreÂ asÂ aÂ simpleÂ averageÂ ofÂ allÂ theseÂ differentÂ dimensionsÂ (9Â dimensionsÂ inÂ total).Â ThisÂ approachÂ indicatesÂ that,Â whenÂ thereÂ areÂ missingÂ valuesÂ inÂ anyÂ givenÂ dimension,Â theseÂ areÂ assumedÂ toÂ beÂ asÂ goodÂ orÂ asÂ badÂ asÂ theÂ dimensionsÂ forÂ whichÂ thereÂ isÂ information.Â WhileÂ thisÂ isÂ notÂ aÂ perfectÂ methodÂ andÂ thereÂ areÂ manyÂ differentÂ waysÂ ofÂ obtainingÂ aÂ compositeÂ scoreÂ basedÂ onÂ theseÂ dimensions,Â theÂ resultingÂ categoriesÂ doÂ notÂ appearÂ toÂ change.Â InÂ addition,Â forÂ theÂ mostÂ part,Â theÂ resultingÂ categoriesÂ seemÂ inâ€?lineÂ withÂ theÂ overallÂ informationÂ aboutÂ theÂ countriesâ€™Â SocialÂ benefitsâ€™Â systems. doc.repnme: Do social benefits respond to crises? Evidence from Europe and Central Asia during the global crisis
doc.abstracts: Social benefits can potentially play an important role in protecting the poor and minimizing the impacts of an economic crisis. While many studies estimate the impacts of a crisis, there is little evidence of the actual response of social safety nets to systematic shocks. This study traces the response of social benefits during the 2008-10 global crisis for 14 countries in Europe and Central Asia (ECA). The study first sets out a framework for defining the 'expected' response of social benefits covering an assessment of pre-crisis preparedness of social benefits and the severity of the crisis for all countries in the ECA region to provide the context; and then develops a typology of all countries categorized by expected response. Using this typology the study analyzes the monthly administrative data on the observed patterns within social benefit programs. Main findings indicate that actual responses were largely in line with expectations. Pre-crisis preparedness clearly influenced the ability of social benefits to respond to the crisis. Unemployment benefits were generally the first line of response in countries that have them, while social assistance programs also expanded coverage during the crisis. Lessons learned from the 2008?2010 global crisis (such as the importance of structural reform, design, and implementation which affect the success of social benefits programs in crisis response) are also presented. The study concludes with some policy recommendations to help ECA countries prepare for future crises.
